American planes delivered police equipment to Haiti's capital to defend the position of the country's newly sworn-in Transitional Council.

While anti-govt. armed groups had called for PM Henry's replacement, which the bourgeois council was meant to facilitate, the rebellion's biggest leader Chérizier warned the new administration of a continuing "war".

Irish Taoiseach Simon Harris has asked the Justice Minister to draft emergency legislation towards deporting potentially thousands of migrant refugees to the United Kingdom.

In the justice committee meeting, Justice Minister Helen McEntee reported 80% of recent asylum seekers had crossed over the open land border from the UK's northern Irish territory. Protesters have accused McEntee of using far-right talking points to defend policy that threatens to undermine Ireland's compliance with the Dublin III rules for the EU asylum process. Ireland will be kicking responsibility over to the UK, which no longer follows these asylum rules, and its new scheme to deport them to Rwanda.

The largest protests in Israel since Oct. 7th took place this weekend.

Featured are the liberal Zionist Yesh Atid, the 2nd largest parliamentary party, and the Communist Youth Movement of Hadash.

7 were arrested for illegal protest and obstruction of roadways in Tel Aviv, and the Maki headquarters in Nazareth was raided the day before their demonstration. 2 people were arrested, including former Hadash secretary Mansour Dahamshe, while preparing the May Day banners.

Blinken was joined by American officials in the spheres of narcotics policing, to address fentanyl production based in China, and cybersecurity, but its reported that yesterday's TikTok ban did not come up in the meeting.

Instead, sanctions were threatened against Chinese companies for selling machine parts to Russia.

They have much to discuss otherwise, with extensive overlapping financial and industrial interests shared between them. At the meeting, Xi stated "the planet is big enough to accommodate the common development and respective prosperity of China and the United States"

A bipartisan bill to repress ongoing pro-Palestine protests at American universities has been submitted to Congress.

The bill would instruct the Department of Education to send "antisemitism monitors" to federally-funded public colleges and revoke funding for any who fail to "combat antisemitism", ie who fail to order their security or call police to shut down sit-in demonstrations against Israel.

Yesterday's "Antisemitism Awareness Act" warns the Dept. of Education against using "alternative definitions" of antisemitism in its investigations of potential discrimination, which "may fail to identify many of the modern manifestations"

Ariel Henry has resigned and Haiti's Finance Minister will continue as Prime Minister while a transitional council of bankers and diplomats sets up elections.

In 2022, Boisvert created a simplified, business-friendly national tax code, and has led the govt since February as interim Prime Minister, declaring curfews to fight unrest.

The transitional council includes the president of the North-East chamber of commerce and former central bank head, a former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, a representative of the Platfòm Pitit Desalin party, a representative of the pro-austerity party OPL, a former senate president of OPL, a pro-Henry senator, a former diplomat of the Aristides party, and Haitian insurance capitalist Laurent Saint-Cyr - directer of business development for the leading insurance and loan provider of the Haitian working class.

Amazon Labor Union Vice-President Valentin-Nieves is running to replace founder Chris Smalls as union president.

She points out that 2 years after the successful ALU unionization vote at New York's JFK8 warehouse, workers still don't have any contract protections from the union.

President Smalls fought to prevent the election from taking place, saying "this is a marathon not a sprint", but ALU was given a court order to hold one after a lawsuit by the Amazon Reform Caucus. Michelle Valentin-Nieves is not affiliated with the Caucus, which is tied to the CPUSA and Labor Notes and is running its own candidate for union president.

Michelle Valentin-Nieves was unanimously elected to the position of VP in 2023 by ALU's Executive Board, after domestic abuse charges were filed against founding VP Derrick Palmer. There has been growing controversy over ALU leadership, with Valentin-Nieves and other organizers blocked from internal ALU discussions, and a recent attempt to oust her from her union officer post without a formal process. In February this year, the union called police to have Valentin-Nieves forcefully removed from a union meeting for disruption. She complained has about 'pro-business' ALU bylaws and called for amendments.

Both union founders Smalls and Palmer were employed by Amazon as management, before the unionization effort. Valentin-Nieves has called-out Amazon warehouse managers for their participation in the exploitative abuse of warehouse staff in exchange for light workload and bonus pay; "I don’t know how these people can live with themselves". In American labor law, supervisors are barred from joining labor bargaining units which represent the workers they supervise.

Israel has set up hundreds of tents in southern Gaza, in the areas of Al-Mawasai and Khan Yunis, for the evacuation of Rafah. The city is the refuge for over half the region's entire Palestinian population, up to 1.4 million people.

Both the US and Egypt have met with Israel in the recent past, clearing diplomatic obstacles for the Rafah offensive to begin imminently.

Once the new mobilization order comes into effect it will be only be possible to issue a foreign passport upon the presentation of a military ID.

The Vietnamese detainees were asked to sign an agreement promising not to disparage the international image of Vietnam; that is, not to undermine the country's diplomatic relations with its allies, the U.S. and Israel.

President Yoon Suk Yeol paid his respects at the April 19th National Cemetery in Seoul, on the anniversary of the 1960 pro-democracy uprising that led the first Korean president to replace Syngman Rhee.

While the Korean ruling class honors its victims and say how they defended democracy, we must not allow them to sweep away their responsibility. The very groups behind Rhee and later dictators remain the great monopolist national capitalists holding sway in the Republic of Korea.

The families of Korea's ruling bourgeoisie are the so-called Chaebols (literally, 'the wealthy clique') whose wealth goes back to their collaboration with the Japanese empire in its Korean colony. It was the monetary support from the Chaebols which supported Rhee's regime of inequality, corruption and the violation of human rights.

It was the Chaebols who were the true backers, along with their US allies, of South Korea's 2nd dictator Park Chung-hee, who again mobilized the army against protesters in 1979. The Chaebols benefitted the most from the monopolization of the Korean market and enshrined their position with a 3rd dictator, Chun Doo-hwan and his massacre of protesters in Gwangju. And it is the Chaebols whose corruption is so entrenched that their bribery of the government goes unchecked, and not a few presidents implicated in taking their money.

Rhee is dead, but the collaborationist bourgeois clique who supported him are still ruling over the country as the owners of the great industrial conglomerates Samsung, Hyundai, LG.

Russia's Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs has proposed to increase the limit on the legal number of consecutive days working overtime.

The Labor Code of the Russian Federation limits consecutive overtime days to 4 hours over 2 days. The proposed increase, reported by the managing director for the union's communications dept. Marina Moskvina, would allow companies to exploit workers more intensely (as its common for companies to coerce the use of overtime) and hire fewer workers to fill those shifts.

Australia's national broadcaster shared this video showing unlicensed backpackers performing dangerous electrical work as part of a gig labor system that the solar farm industry relies on.

The Electrical Trades Union (ETU) found on one solar farm that half of the workers were backpackers, performing the duties of a trained electrician for which they were not qualified. One worker described the solar farm's facilities as power stations, which pose a serious threat of electrocution to the unskilled temporary workers. Unlicensed electrical work is just one of the many safety violations occurring every day in these vast fields of solar panels.

Australia, like many nations, is moving towards green energy. But in order to continue the push for wind and solar farms, breaches in workers' rights and safety must be swept under the rug. Politicians benefit from the political mandate for green energy by claiming ethical and moral reasons for development, and thereby the concerns of workers are 'justly' ignored.

Los Angeles mayor Karen Bass asked "the most fortunate" to fund housing for the homeless.

While saying the homelessness crisis "has affected everyone in the city", the solution somehow remains solely in the power of the richest 3% of Americans.

Emphasizing her supposed helplessness in the face of immense social issues, she has said that "we do not have a way of preventing homelessness". Oh, really?

In the UK, it was determined that it would cost $12.5 billion to accommodate the nations' homeless. In the United States, this number is as low as $20 billion, a tiny fraction for a national budget that exceeds 4.4 trillion. The capitalist state commands vast resources to fund social policy, it just doesn't do so.

To them, social expenses are just that — expenses. Homelessness is a fundamental problem for, as Bass says "safety issues" and the normal functioning of the city, but safely neglected for years until it began "driving away businesses and customers, costing taxpayers city resources".

A new mass-bleaching of coral may become the worst ever, affecting over 50%, leading scientists to create new levels of alarm to categorize the danger. These organisms are vital to the ocean ecosystems, and severe heat in the immediate future may have long-term effects.

Since August 2023, ocean temperatures have been consistently above average, and in February they broke the 21°C record (~70°F) set back then. New records for heat have been set every day for the past year. As the southern hemisphere enters its autumnal season, these are grim tidings for the world's reefs.

Israel has stated they will retaliate against Iran for its attack Saturday night. Reports say this attack is imminent.

Even before the Iranian attack struck, U.S. military promised its full support to actively defend Israel. Assembling its warships and allies, the U.S. intercepted a large number of the Iranian projectiles.

Despite this, the U.S. claims it will be neutral in the coming Israeli attack.

None of these actions support de-escalation, and only further the capitalistic goal of war and competition over spheres of influence in the region. Israel is turning its attention to the war with Iran, against the supposed 'advice' of the U.S., not away from it. The capitalist forces are not afraid of a wider, even more horrific war in the region, in which each seeks to benefit from undermining the sphere of the other.

The European Commission may sue Germany over its tax on gas export sales.

According to a senior EC representative, "There are grounds to consider this a clear violation of the competition law and the rules of the single market." 

He indicates that this 2022 rule undermines the EU's efforts to reduce member states' dependence on Russia, raising prices for Germany's neighbors, particularly those smaller nations such as Czechia and Austria, pushing them to buy cheap Russian gas. 

Germany for its own part instituted the law after years of declining gas exports, while being one of the world's biggest gas importers, and in 2022 hoped to increase the state's own slice of the narrowing monopoly pie. It has also doubled the fee on the use of its gas storage tanks, extracting every drop they can from the relative strength of their industrial development.

The great owning classes take care of their own needs, exploiting every crisis and dealing with the enemy to guarantee their own profits.

Truong My Lan, a Vietnamese real-estate mogul and one of the world's richest female billionaires has been sentence to death for embezzling $44bn. 

Spun as a "victory" of the Vietnamese government by opportunists, they don't question how was this situation was possible in a supposedly socialist country? The courts never had a problem with her wealth before, and clearly it did not come from her working 1000x harder than the average Vietnamese worker. The unspoken mechanism of her decades long rise is capitalist exploitation - the mass theft of the value produced by the working class.

Would it really be so much more just and moral if she acquired this $44 billion "legally"? How can justice be found in the trial of one women when the crimes of her entire class are upheld as good and just at the same time.

Russian state control of Wagner assets also includes the company's valuable mining capital, put to use in places such as Libya and Sudan.

Australian Federal court has dismissed a case against controlled burning in Strathbogie Forest, Victoria, which destroys the only habitat of the southern greater glider, a rare marsupial listed as endangered only 2 years ago in the wake of the 2020 Australian bushfires.

Fuel reduction involve strategic burning of forested areas, to make bushfires more manageable, however their effectiveness is being scientifically questioned. In this case, the greater gliders which live in the area rely on hollows in dead, standing trees particularly destroyed by the frequent burns.

Meanwhile, pine plantation has taken over the forest in recent decades, and all because capitalism puts profit ahead over scientific understanding and ecology.

Congolese protesters threw stones at UN troops yesterday, accusing them of collaborating with the invading M23, responsible for atrocities including the murder of hundreds of people on behalf of their allies in Rwanda.

Last week, the United Nations MONUSCO police forces deployed Indian troops to prevent the town's capture by the Rwandan army and proxy M23 forces. Now, this ill-advised retreat has allowed these forces to seize 3 of the UN's defensive positions around the town which sits on a critical logistical route 12 miles west from the besieged capital of North Kivu.

US sources have almost completely stopped reporting on the conquest of DR Congo by their ally Rwanda.

The West is increasingly losing its confidence in winning the battle for Ukraine, and so looks desperately around the map to avoid conceding defeat. To the contrary, whichever side wins, more and more of the world will be dragged into the inter-imperialist struggle for the redivision of the global market.

Denmark announced the Great Belt strait, a major shipping lane, will be closed to planes and ships due to the failure of a naval missile launcher during military exercises.

Yet another pricey restriction arises for commercial shipping, but instead of undermining Capital's profits, their monopoly isn't threatened one bit. Whilst this pause is unlikely to have a long-term effect like the Suez closure or the Straits of Aden crisis, these crises are still an opportunity for monopolization. As ship traffic tightens and costs mount, smaller firms are absorbed into those with excess hoards of money, freeing these monopolies to increase shipping fees as they choose.

Thousands of workers from state-owned textile factories in Mahalla, working for one of the most important companies in Egypt, struck against their exclusion from the new state employee benefits package which increased the minimum wage.

7,000 workers rallied in the factory square at the strike's inception, calling for wage increases beyond the state minimum.

This came at the same time the Egyptian state inaugurated what it says is the world's largest textile factory, a $32 billion, 24,000 sq. mile complex in the same city, which they claim could create 17,000 jobs.

While the state conceded their E£6,000 minimum wage, it denied all other demands and detained a number of strikers after the strike was resolved.

South West Water (a private regional water monopoly), in response to potential lawsuits over the dumping of sewage onto English beaches, claims the public has no legal right to swim in the ocean.

Experts warn that the majority of all swimmers in the UK risk adverse health effects due to inadequate warning systems about the dumping.

The company says they have no legal obligation to keep rivers or coastal seas clean for the purposes of swimming when they dump waste water. These intentional releases by South West Water don't just include the residue of human waste, but also high levels of toxic, cancer-causing chemicals.

The Japanese Trade Union Confederation has succeeded in winning a 5.25% wage increase, the largest since 1991. While the efforts of the Japanese workers cannot be discounted in our understanding of the present growth in international labor activity, we must look at the larger picture.

This 'increase' comes after 22 months of declining real wage.

Lough Neagh, the largest lake in the UK, is being contaminated by toxic algae. This Northern Irish Lake succumbing to toxic algae has unleashed a dire environmental crisis. Fish populations are plummeting, and the growth of toxic algae is rendering the lake a noxious and un-swimmable expanse. The root cause of this catastrophe lies in the relentless dumping of fertilizers into the lake resulting in eutrophication. Eutrophication is a process by which a body of water becomes progressively enriched with minerals and nutrients, namely phosphorous and nitrogen, which thereby stimulates the growth of algae. This tragic situation not only imperils the livelihoods of local residents who depend on the lake for sustenance (it is the source of 40% of Northern Ireland’s drinking water), as well as economic life but also poses a severe threat to the wildlife that calls Lough Neagh home.

❗️Marx turned out to be right: according to the latest research, a new crisis of overproduction may break out

According to a study by the Russian MIEL group of companies (and later we will rely on it), in recent months, the number of transactions in the Russian real estate market concluded on a mortgage varied between 70-80%. Before February 2022, there were less than 60% of such deals.

This growth in the «popularity» of mortgages is due to two factors:
🔻 First, the fall in mortgage rates. In this way, banks are probably trying to cash in on the increase in the number of mortgage holders. According to the Central Bank of the Russian Federation, today, the rate is slightly over 3%, although back in April this year, it was about 6%. The Central Bank of the Russian Federation expresses concerns about this.
🔻 Secondly, the inaccessibility of housing. The «classic» coefficient of access to housing (CAH) calculation shows that the average Moscow family would have to save up for a one-room apartment for more than 7 years. And this coefficient does not consider inflation, rental costs, etc. In 2020, this coefficient was 4 years.

The rapid growth in the number of people purchasing housing on a mortgage in the face of a decline in the population's well-being may lead to massive debts or non-payments. A similar situation occurred in the US in 2007, which was additionally exacerbated by the floating nature of the rate.

All this is happening against the backdrop of a constant increase in the supply of primary housing. Since January 2021, the number of lots on the primary market (new building) has almost doubled to 61,000. Demand, on the contrary, is falling: actual sales have been at a minimum since the beginning of 2021.

❗️This is the crisis of overproduction: houses are built, but no one can buy them — therefore, they will have to mothball them or destroy them, like in China. A mortgage is issued, but not everyone can pay for it.

In 2007–2009 in the United States, under similar conditions, the number of homeless people had increased by 10%, and the number of unemployed doubled due to the crisis. The losses to the economy were estimated at trillions of dollars. The crisis was extended to most countries of the world, which led to a significant decline in the so-called «middle class» — the main pride of modern capitalism.

The same mortgage crisis in Russia could lead to profound social upheavals in a tense world.

On May 30, 1937, police opened fire on a workers' demonstration in Chicago. This incident is called the Memorial Day Massacre.

In March 1937, the metalworkers' union SWOC signed an agreement with the largest steel company, U.S. Steel. The agreement fixed an 8-hour workday, a wage standard, and limited overtime.

However, other companies in the industry refused to make concessions. The union negotiated, but the "entrepreneurs" dragged their feet and tried to intimidate the workers. Spies were infiltrated into the union, activists were kidnapped and beaten, and criminal cases were brought against them. The companies openly prepared for war with the workers, purchasing $40,000 worth of machine guns, revolvers, shotguns, ammunition, and tear gas - violence was more profitable than concessions to the workers.

In May 1937, the steelworkers responded with a strike. On May 30, the strikers marched to the Republic Steel plant, where police opened fire on the crowd. Ten people were killed and about forty more were shot; the dispersal was caught on camera, which was rare at the time. Neither the police nor the company were held accountable for the killings, and the press called the demonstration a "red riot" and circulated fakes that the protesters were led by "marijuana-smoking communists.

The Yalta Conference of 1945, a conference of the heads of government of the three powers allied in the Second World War of 1939-1945-the USSR, the USA, Great Britain: Chairman of the SNK of the USSR I. V. Stalin, US President F. D. Roosevelt and British Prime Minister W. Churchill with the participation of foreign ministers, chiefs of staff, etc. the advisors. 

It took place in Yalta on February 4-11, at a time when, as a result of the powerful offensive attacks of the Soviet Army, which transferred military operations to German territory, the war against Hitler's Germany entered the final stage. The war plans of the Powers for the final defeat of fascist Germany were agreed upon, their attitude towards Germany after its unconditional surrender was determined, and the basic principles of the general policy towards the post-war organization of the world were outlined. 

It was decided that after the German armed resistance was finally crushed, the armed forces of the USSR, the United States and Great Britain would occupy Germany; and the troops of each of the mentioned powers would occupy a certain part (zone) of Germany. It also provided for the creation of a coordinated allied administration in Germany and the establishment of control, carried out through a specially created control body consisting of the commanders-in-chief of the three powers, with the seat in Berlin. At the same time, it was indicated that France would be invited to take over a certain zone of occupation and participate as the fourth member of this control body. 

The specific resolution of the issue of occupation zones of Germany was achieved before the K. K. in the European Advisory Commission and recorded in the Protocol of the Agreement between the governments of the USSR, USA and the United Kingdom occupation zones of Germany and about the management of 'Big Berlin''dated September 12, 1944. The participants of the conference stated that their unwavering goal is to destroy German militarism and Nazism and to create guarantees that ' Germany will never again be able to violate

According to the theory of socialism, i.e., of Marxism (non Marxist socialism is not worth serious discussion nowadays), the real driving force of history is the revolutionary class struggle; reforms are a subsidiary product of this struggle, subsidiary because they express unsuccessful attempts to weaken, to blunt this struggle, etc. According to the theory of bourgeois philosophers, the driving force of progress is the unity of all elements in society who realise the “imperfections” of certain of its institutions.
